@siminevazire discusses finding a balance between keeping an open mind about the possibility that you're wrong versus not being overly persuaded by people disingenuously arguing you're wrong because they want to keep the status quo.

Q: Did your reform activity cause feelings of alienation?

@deevybee says social media can connect you with like-minded community (in addition to the toxic elements). @drEmilySena suggests getting broad experience in your area to communicate as a peer rather than an outsider.

@MalikaIhle says to attend field-specific open research societies to look for PhD and postdoctoral supervisors who share your values.  (You can also get involved in team science groups like @PsySciAcc @Many_Babies @ManyPrimates @BrRepInitiative)
@aidybarnett mentions that sometimes the best option is to change labs (if possible), especially when the lab methods can be classed as misconduct.

Q from the audience: How do PhD students convince reluctant PIs to engage in research reform?

@deevybee suggests arguing that funders and journals will start requiring open practices, and positioning yourself as a person who can bring these skills to the lab.
@MalikaIhle is a strong proponent of grassroots activism to create change from the bottom up. These initiatives can often be more inclusive than the existing structures that can make change top-down.

Both @drEmilySena and @deevybee caution against factionalisation in the open science community. If the reform community is divided into groups who think their way is the only way, we won't make as much progress.

Q: What is the relationship between equality/inclusion and open research? @drEmilySena points out the global biases in research and the gender & ethnic biases in leadership in western countries. @deevybee points out that this work shouldn't all fall on marginalised people.

@siminevazire observes that really understanding the extent of research problems leads some people to conclude that it cannot be real, because the alternative is too big and devastating to contemplate.

@deevybee reminds us that many people are still not aware of the extent of problems. (We can get in a bubble and think the average level of knowledge about open research is much higher than it is.) Incentives can also work against change.
@aidybarnett also observes a lot of inertia in the system. He suggests randomised trials of funding strategies to determine what leads to more robust research.
@drEmilySena observes that most people and groups feel they don't have sufficient power to change the entrenched system.

@deevybee makes the great point that change requires both buy-in at the grassroots level and also change at an institutional level. Funders' requirements have a huge capacity to drive change at institutions and by individuals.
Back at #AIMOS2021: How to start a revolution in your discipline with @siminevazire, @deevybee, @drEmilySena, @MalikaIhle, and @aidybarnett

Reviewers have more power than authors to demand transparency. Editors are so desperate for reviewers that if everyone who declined a review cited the lack of transparency, they‚Äôd probably change their policies quickly.
I recently spent 6 hours on a review (for a registered report) and I‚Äôd love it to be public so I can reference the points I made (and code I wrote) when addressing the same issues in the future.

Question time: Why don't journals make reviews open to decrease bad behaviour? Some mention that editors might fear reviewers won't accept reviews anymore. The counterpoint was that some reviewers want their reviews to be open to get credit and for others to learn from them.
Journal-agnostic peer review, like at @PCI_RegReports avoids some of the problems of peer review.

@antica_c makes the point that league tables or badges for open data and code can be misleading because so many ostensibly open datasets are not actually reusable because they are poorly documented or don't contain all necessary information.

@Tom_Hardwicke makes the point that tools for computational reproducibility usually enhance your workflow if you embed them in the research process, but they do slow things down if they're an afterthought, so editors are reluctant to mandate them.

@rianaminocher makes the great point that sometimes it's easier to re-write the analysis code than to figure out what's going on in poorly documented shared code. Researchers need to invest more in code check and team members with reproducible coding expertise.

Executable research articles looks like a great initiative for promoting computational reproducibility.

https://t.co/l0teCSo3CO

I finally get the Fleishman 3rd order polynomial method for simulating data with specific skewness and kurtosis. 

Caveat1: this method only works if 
kurtosis >= skewness^2 - 2

Caveat2: estimating population kurtosis reliably requires huge samples

Quick way to calculate these bounds for continuous values:

-simulate ~1M values from each distribution
-sort them both ascending and correlate (upper bound)
-sort one ascending and one descending and correlate (lower bound)
@oscar_olvera100 makes the point that simulation papers that don‚Äôt create multivariate non-normal distributions correctly often report data for correlations outside these bounds.

Fr√©chet-Hoefding bounds are the limits to a correlation between different distributions. At the extreme, it‚Äôs obvious that a normal distribution and a uniform distribution can‚Äôt be correlated 1.0, because they wouldn‚Äôt be different distributions then.

I suspect my next few twitch streams will be me trying to implement this method in faux so you can specify the distribution of each variable. I‚Äôll probably take a simulation approach rather than evaluating double integrals.

The NORTA method involves evaluating double integrals for the general case to determine the adjusted correlation matrix to use for the pre-converted multivariate normal distribution so that the converted values have the desired correlations.

Faux has distribution conversion functions (basically wrappers for the paired pnorm and q{dist} functions with some error checking), but conversion alters multivariate correlations.

@CMastication This is better to sim arrivals/min for 10 min

simrep <- 100000
av_per_min <- tibble(
  id = rep(1:(simrep/10), length.out = simrep),
  arrivals = rpois(n = simrep, lambda = 5.8/60),
  min = rep(1:10, each = simrep/10)
) %>%
  pivot_wider(names_from = min, values_from = arrivals)

@CMastication av_per_min <- tibble(
 arrivals = rpois(n = 100000, lambda = 5.8/60)
) %>%
  count(arrivals) %>%
  mutate(prob = n/sum(n)) %>%
  crossing(min = 1:10) %>%
  mutate(min_prob = round(prob^min, 4)) %>%
  pivot_wider(names_from = min, values_from = min_prob) https://t.co/qDSPihue2q

@seriousstats @manes This is my exact wheelhouse (cross-classified GLMM for face studies) so DM me @felixgrnd if you want to chat over the design and analysis. If it would benefit from reanalysis with a model that better fits the design, that could make an interesting follow-up.

@manes @seriousstats I think it will be hard to clear this up without the R code. Mixed effects models have a terrible jingle-jangle problem, so it‚Äôs nearly impossible to describe them coherently with just prose.

@manes Kudos for the very thorough supplemental materials and pre-reg deviation documentation, @felixgrnd! It says the trials were nested in participants, but shouldn‚Äôt the stimulus IDs be *crossed* with participants? Is there open code? This might just be a terminology difference.

@manes Awesome! They have data on the OSF. I can‚Äôt read it on my phone (and if I get my laptop out I‚Äôll be up all night), but the analysis word doc lists the 36 image IDs, so it looks likely that there is only 1 identity per cell, or maybe emotion was counterbalanced between ID?

@manes If that‚Äôs the case and you account for face identity in a mixed effects analysis, 1 trial per cell is probably not a problem, especially if face ethnicity, gender and emotion aren‚Äôt part of the focal hypothesis. (Not sure what the paper‚Äôs focus is, but looks interesting!)
@manes Maybe they counterbalanced identity between subjects but didn‚Äôt mention it? Otherwise it‚Äôs an amazing example of maximally confounded stimuli.

@DeonTBenton To be fair to students, they often don't know (nor do I expect them to know) if their question can be answered with a simple yes/no or if I'll have to spend 20 minutes clearing up a fundamental misunderstanding or gap in their background knowledge. Coding is hard that way!

@RaziehPourafshi @CDelawalla @aidangcw A few sentences about your experience and interests is fine. I just feel bad when someone writes me a 5-paragraph email with an attached CV and their thesis, and all I write back is I don't have funding. But opinions are probably diverse.

@DeonTBenton I try to insist people ask questions on the Teams channel so at least then everyone can benefit from the answers, but they're often insecure for others to see their questions. If one person gets the courage to ask a question, you can be sure a dozen others have the same one.

@DeonTBenton I sympathise with your annoyance, though. Poorly organised emails full of questions are really hard to answer satisfyingly. You often need some back-and-forth to figure out what the broader conceptual issue or misunderstanding is.

@DeonTBenton I was just complaining about the opposite of this the other day: students insisting on booking extra office hours with me to ask a 1-sentence question with a yes/no answer that would have been quicker to type than the meeting scheduling messages.

@RaziehPourafshi @CDelawalla @aidangcw This lets me respond with something like "Sorry, I don't have any funded places." or "Sorry, I don't have capacity to take new students." or "I have a funded place that you might be able to apply for if you're interested in [topic]. Tell me more about your experience & skills."

@RaziehPourafshi @CDelawalla @aidangcw I'm happy for the cold email to be *very* short, like:

I'm interested in a PhD in [topic] and wondered if you're taking students next year. I [have/am looking for] funding. Let me know if you'd like to hear more about my background and study ideas.

@RaziehPourafshi @CDelawalla @aidangcw Those sorts of emails often read like spam and get ignored. If there isn't a very clear indication that the person knows something about my research, has an even vaguely relevant background, and specifically wants to do a PhD with me, I don't respond.
